quoted.text:
This is What Winning Looks Like From Space

Satellite imagery just caught xAI doing something no press release ever could: painting MACROHARD across the roof of its Colossus 2 datacenter in Tennessee. A building-sized wink at Microsoft, visible from orbit, impossible to ignore.

It reads like a joke, until you look at what‚Äôs underneath.

‚öÜ Colossus 2 isn‚Äôt a concept site or a slide in a deck. Power and cooling infrastructure are expanding in lockstep, with the campus pushing toward ~400 MW of active capacity in the near term. Gas turbines are arriving. Cooling towers are multiplying. The build is loud because the progress is real.

‚öÜ More importantly, this early ramp sits on a much larger foundation. xAI has secured a clear path towards large scale on-site generation, creating a credible trajectory toward more than 2 GW of IT capacity over time. This isn‚Äôt aspirational: it‚Äôs ordered hardware, permitted infrastructure, and steel on the ground.

The subtext is clear: while others debate timelines, this campus is already running. The roof says MACROHARD. The infrastructure says we‚Äôre ahead.

quoted.text: We're now #1 on the App Store in South Korea! üá∞üá∑ https://t.co/HvdbuZbaPm

üá∫üá∏ GROK IS COOKING GEMINI AND USERS ARE SWITCHING FAST

Grok now has more daily active users in the U.S. than Gemini, a big signal that people are actively choosing which AI they actually want to open every day.

It also holds a 4.9 stars and + rating, the highest among major AI apps, showing users clearly vibe more with it than with stiffer, over filtered alternatives.

A big reason is Elon pouring money, talent, and infrastructure into xAI, wiring Grok straight into X, real time data, and a move fast culture that keeps shipping updates.

While Gemini feels like a corporate school assignment, Grok feels plugged into the real internet, and adoption keeps accelerating because regular users feel the difference.

Source: @elonmusk, @grok

quoted.text:
Here is one surprisingly elegant equivalent reformulation of the Riemann Hypothesis: Let B be the pointwise maximal function on [0,1] satisfying B(0) = B(1) = 0 and 2B((x+y)/2) ‚â§ B(x) + B(y) + |x - y| for all x and y in [0,1]. Extend it periodically to all the real line.

As Grok correctly notes, this is Takagi function (or blancmange curve), with a fractal-like graph. It is continuous, nowhere differentiable, and less well-known than the Weierstrass function.
 
This function also emerged recently (and independently) in a joint work https://t.co/pgJw9MaEA1  with my student, Natanael Alpay, as a sharp lower bound for the L^1 norm of the square function applied to indicator functions of sets. I was unaware at the time that it is known as the Takagi function or of its connection to the Riemann Hypothesis. Large language models will undoubtedly accelerate scientific discoveries by forging connections across diverse fields of science.

tweets.text: RT @Teslaconomics: I‚Äôve researched so many founders and CEOs in my lifetime bc it‚Äôs the most important thing when it comes to investing. An‚Ä¶

retweet.text:
I‚Äôve researched so many founders and CEOs in my lifetime bc it‚Äôs the most important thing when it comes to investing. And I‚Äôve realized more and more that the difference between Elon and most founders or CEOs is very simple and super rare.

Many CEOs lead and give orders from an ivory tower, while Elon is always and willing to fight in the trenches with his people. While many CEOs give orders from a far, Elon is hands on with everything at Tesla. He‚Äôs on the factory floor. In the engineering and design room. In uncomfortable situations and makes the tough decisions. On top of this, he directly uses the products him and the team builds first hand and is wiling to put his heath and life at risk in doing so.

I remember when he was willing to risk arrest during COVID rather than shut down what his team was fighting to build. He put his own freedom on the line because he believed in the mission and in the people behind it.

‚ÄúTesla is restarting production today against Alameda County rules. I will be on the line with everyone else. If anyone is arrested, I ask that it only be me.‚Äù - Elon Musk

This kind of leadership is different.

When your CEO is willing to take the hits for the team, sleep on the factory floor, and personally stand in front of the fire, it creates trust that he will NEVER let Tesla fail.

Real leaders don‚Äôt hide, they step forward, as one.

user.name: Teslaconomics

quoted.text:
What is @grok? It is deep empathy! 

From Heinlein‚Äôs Stranger in a Strange Land:

Grok means "identically equal". The human clich√© "This hurts me worse than it does you" has a distinctly Martian flavor. The Martian seems to know instinctively what we learned painfully from modern physics, that observer acts with observed through the process of observation. Grokmeans to understand so thoroughly that the observer becomes a part of the observed¬†‚Äî to merge, blend, intermarry, lose identity in group experience. It means almost everything that we mean by religion, philosophy, and science and it means as little to us as color does to a blind man.

tweets.text: RT @Teslaconomics: If your CEO is literally riding in the passenger seat while the car drives itself around a major U.S. city, with no safe‚Ä¶

retweet.text:
If your CEO is literally riding in the passenger seat while the car drives itself around a major U.S. city, with no safety monitor in the vehicle, that‚Äôs about as bullish of a signal you can send to the market that autonomy is here and Tesla has solved it.

This is Elon Musk, in Austin, letting Tesla‚Äôs AI do 100% of the work, confident enough in the technology to remove the last human supervision inside the vehicle.

What honesty makes this moment special to me is how long it‚Äôs been coming.

Tesla first talked about full autonomy back in 2016, when FSD was introduced as a long-term software promise. Since then, we‚Äôve had
‚Ä¢ years of real world data collection
‚Ä¢ multiple hardware generations
‚Ä¢ vision only going against industry consensus of LiDAR
‚Ä¢ endless doubt and skepticism, delays, and ‚Äúit‚Äôll never work‚Äù headlines

This is nearly a decade of hard work and intelligent iterations to reach this moment.

When the person with the most to lose is willing to trust the system with his own life, this debate now ends overnight. We‚Äôve been waiting for this day for almost 10 years‚Ä¶ 

Elon may not always be on time, may be very optimistic at times, but he and his team always delivers. 

Damn, it feels good to be a retail Tesla investor.
